title: Do writers usually write their books in the order they are read? Or do they write the chapters randomly and piece them together afterwards? - Quora

response.answer_text: When I write, I write in scenes and later cobble them together in chapters. To me, a scene is on that has a unity of space, time and perspective (point of view).And I ensure that scene has its own beginning, middle and end. Because of my background as a playwright, i tend to use the same techniques of drama- using rising action, falling action, beats etc. I try to make sure that the book itself begins in media res— or in the middle of the story, preferably in some action scene— or a scene that immediately brings out the conflict. The order in which I write may depend on the mood and the setting. for instance, in my latest novel, I wrote the scenes in Pondicherry whike visiting. I write climatic and other important scenes only when i am in the flow. Since I write the scenes in no particular order, I use Scrivener, which is a great piece of writing software which allows me to stitch the complete novel together any which way. Sometimes, because of the way I write, I need transitioning sentences at the end of some of the scenes/chapters. Different writers have different methods. There are the strict outliners who know in advance to a great degree the plot, the chapters and the scenes they are going to write. These people are likely to write int the order of reading. then are the ‘pantsers’ — who follow a seat-of-the-pants approach. These writers will probably never write in the reading order.

I’ve done both. They both work. If you write in a non-linear manner, then the first full edit is a crucial step to assuring continuity, and you may have to make some major changes. The advantage to random order, especially for a beginner, is that you get to work on the scene that excites you, and if you are stuck on something you can leave it behind for a while. The disadvantage is that continuity can be a bear, as you can forget where in the text plot elements were introduced, because “before” and “after” has no relation to the writing process.

I don't know about other writers, but I, myself, do both. I start out my books in Google Doc, write down chapters in order. But of course, mind always runs faster than the pen/cursor: I am almost often thinking about Chapter 20 when I'm writing Chapter 5. So I also maintain another writing software where I write down whatever that comes to my mind at the moment, following no order. Sometimes, I write the same chapter twice. Sometimes, I write down different plot twists. Most of the times, they are ‘practices': I don't always add them exactly to the main novel, but rewrite them or use bits and pieces of them in the main writing piece.

It’s impossible to say what writers do, because there is no hard and fast rule we all of us. We not only have our own preferred approach to doing the writing, but our preferred approach varies from project to project. I generally make a fairly complete outline of the book as I am planning it. Then, with this “road map” to follow, I start with chapter 1 and write the rough draft in order. The important thing is to actually write your book, not just think about, and plan and re-plan. Write it—in whatever way works best for you. Write on!

I tend to be very linear — I’ve only a few times had such a powerful drive to write a scene from further along that I took advantage of that energy to get it written down, then filled in the gap. That said, I’m taking more of that approach with my current work-in-progress. I’m not sure why except that I’m strapped for time right now, and so when I get writing time, I’m inclined to write the scenes I imagine the most vividly. It’s a little unsettling to take a different approach — but we’ll see how it goes.

Many projects I've worked on began with an idea for a specific scene. So naturally, when I decided to sit and start writing those stories, I began with that scene. Many times that scene wasn't the first event in the story, though. So I went back and wrote the scenes building up to what I just penned. If I'm inspired to write a certain part of a story, I'm going to write that part of the story. I don't care if it fits chronologically with what I've already wrote. I'll make it fit eventually. I just need to write! Hope this helps...

If you are writing non-fiction, an outline will help you get organized. However, you can write any part of the book in any order you like. You don’t have to start on page one and force your way to the end. I find that method is liberating because some days you want to write something easy; other days you have more power to write a tougher section. The reader doesn’t care in which order you wrote the book. Just get it done! Good luck!

Different writers write in different ways. When I write fiction, I tend to write linearly from beginning to end. I know other writers who write key scenes first, and then fill in the places between those scenes. As with many things in life, different individuals have different approaches.

Personally I’ve always found that it’s easier to start at the beginning and tell the story all the way through. Now, I’ll admit that I sometimes get writers block, and write something that hasn’t happened yet, but on the whole I try to write chronologically.
I have a fairly detailed outline that allows me to write scenes out of order if I feel like it. That being said, I rarely write too much out of order unless the scene is bursting out of me.
I write in order, start to finish. That isn’t to say the book happens in order, I just write in order. I’m kind of weird, I don’t outline or anything, just go through and get like 98% down in one go.
“Do writers usually write their books in the order they are read? Or do they write the chapters randomly and piece them together afterwards?” Yes.
